node.title: Theo Hayez inquest told data access reform could save lives
node.alt: A young man wearing a black hoodie stands against a brick wall.
node.description:
Authorities face significant barriers to accessing data that could make all the difference the search for a missing person, the inquest into the disappearance of the Belgian backpacker hears.




A court has heard the family of missing Belgian backpacker Theo Hayez support potential reforms from the 18-year-old's coronial inquest which could help spare other families similar grief.
node.content:
["The second week of the coronial inquest into the\u00a0disappearance of Belgian backpacker Theo Hayez will examine the legislative gaps and barriers in obtaining fast access to crucial data in missing persons cases.", "Theo Hayez was last seen leaving the Cheeky Monkeys nightclub in Byron Bay at about\u00a011pm on May 31, 2019.", "Mobile phone data obtained by his family showed that the 18-year-old searched for directions back to his hostel near Belongil Beach, but then\u00a0travelled in the opposite direction.", "The data showed he stopped for seven minutes at a park before taking a dark and secluded bush track towards Tallow Beach.", "The working police theory is that he fell into the ocean while trying to climb up towards the Cape Byron lighthouse.", "But\u00a0Theo's family believe he was not alone\u00a0and that there must be more to his disappearance.", "So far the\u00a0inquest has\u00a0heard from a number of Theo's family and friends, who described him as being averse to risk-taking, heavy\u00a0drinking and drugs.", "Backpackers who were with him on the night he disappeared have said he did not seem drunk.", "The second week of the inquest resumed today with an opening address\u00a0from Counsel Assisting the Coroner Kirsten Edwards, who identified\u00a0a number of areas where improvements could be made to help police find missing people and \"potentially save\u00a0their lives\".", "", "
Police searching\u00a0the Byron headland after Theo's disappearance.(AAP: Dave Hunt)
", "
Jurisdiction a 'foundational issue'
", "Ms Edwards said a\u00a0\"foundational issue\" in missing\u00a0persons investigations in New South Wales was that they fell into a jurisdictional \"grey area\".", "She said police had a range of powers in criminal investigations that did not extend to missing persons cases.", "Examples included the power to search people, cars and houses, and to seize objects like phones and computers.", "Another limitation, Ms Edwards said, was the inability of police to require an individual or business to provide CCTV footage or other crucial information\u00a0in missing persons cases.", "Ms Edwards said the Wake Up! hostel had provided important evidence like guest logs and contact information, but was not legally obliged to.", "\"It\u2019s voluntary and at least theoretically could be withdrawn at any time,\" she said.", "", "
CCTV footage of Theo Hayez\u00a0on the night he went missing.(Supplied)
", "
Data laws 'have not kept\u00a0pace'
", "The inquest heard that despite how crucial mobile phone data had been in Theo's case, there were significant barriers and time delays that prevented police gaining access.", "Ms Edwards said many multinational social media corporations had\u00a0policies about disclosing data and would only provide it to authorities if they were legally compelled to.", "She said NSW Police did not have any legislative power to issue search warrants, notices to produce or subpoenas to international companies in missing persons cases.", "\"Police can request some information under normal processes,\" Ms Edwards said.", "", "
Belgian backpacker Theo Hayez disappeared on the night of May 31, 2019.(Supplied)
", "The inquest heard there were also legislative barriers to police gaining access to computer data for missing persons cases.", "\"Sadly, it could be argued that legislation has not kept pace with these developments in modern technology,\" Ms Edwards said.", "\"We understand from our work that there have been huge advances in criminal investigations, but missing persons investigations have\u00a0not received the same focus and powers in this area remain very limited.\"", "Ms Edwards said some social media companies did not have any points of contact for law enforcement authorities, and others \u2013\u00a0like Snapchat and WhatsApp, which\u00a0use encrypted messages \u2013 were unlikely to provide data, even in serious criminal investigations.", "She said\u00a0technology, including mobile phones, were not mentioned at all in the Coroner's Act.", "", "
A map of Theo's movements, based on mobile phone data.(Supplied: NSW Coroner's Court)
", "
Prompt release 'may avert imminent threat'
", "Ms Edwards said one process of \"tremendous\" value to missing persons investigations were\u00a0emergency disclosure requests, which allowed authorities rapid access to data\u00a0in emergencies.", "She said each company had a different policy, but Google had shown the\u00a0potential impact of quickly releasing data\u00a0in missing persons cases.", "\"Google can provide data to public authorities within hours \u2026 where Google has a good faith belief that disclosure of the data without delay may avert an imminent threat to life,\" Ms Edwards said.", "She said there were a number of critical factors in making the request, including knowing that the avenue\u00a0was available, providing the correct information and knowing a\u00a0particular company's criteria for accessing an\u00a0emergency request.", "In Theo's case, she said police tried to access Theo's Google account on June 8 and 9, 2019, but could not find a way to make an emergency request, despite consulting with a number of specialist units in the police force.", "The emergency request was routine practice for Belgian authorities and the data was passed onto NSW Police through the Belgian embassy.", "Ms Edwards acknowledged\u00a0that while any reforms to come out of the inquest were unlikely to help in Theo's case, his family had made it very clear that they did not want anyone else to have the same experience."]
